paragraphs.text: Zn induced in-gap electronic states in La214 probed by uniform magnetic susceptibility: relevance to the suppression of superconducting T c
Substitution of isovalent non-magnetic defects, such as Zn, in the CuO 2 plane strongly modifies the magnetic properties of strongly electron correlated hole doped cuprate superconductors.
The reason for enhanced uniform magnetic susceptibility, χ, in Zn substituted cuprates is debatable.
Generally the defect induced magnetic behavior has been analyzed mainly in terms of two somewhat contrasting scenarios.

The first one is due to independent localized moments appearing in the vicinity of Zn arising because of the strong electronic/magnetic correlations present in the host compound and the second one is due to transfer of quasiparticle (QP) spectral weight and creation of weakly localized low-energy electronic states associated with each Zn atom in place of an in-plane Cu.

If the second scenario is correct, one should expect a direct correspondence between Zn induced suppression of the superconducting transition temperature, T c , and the extent of the enhanced magnetic susceptibility at low temperature.
In this case, the low-T enhancement of χ would be due to weakly localized QP states at low energy and these electronic states will be precluded from taking part in Cooper pairing.
We explore this second possibility by analyzing the χ(T) data for La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 with different hole contents, p (=x), and Zn concentrations (y) in this paper.

spans.text: La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4

attributes.material0_resolvedFormula_0: La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4
attributes.material0_formula: La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4
attributes.material0_rawTaggedValue: <formula>La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4</formula>

paragraphs.text: The results of our analysis support this scenario.
High-T c cuprates, effect of disorder, magnetic susceptibility, pseudogap, pair- breaking

The observation that isovalent non-magnetic defects in CuO 2 planes of hole doped cuprates reduces the superconducting T c most effectively , triggered a surge of theoretical and experimental activities since the early days of their discovery.
Besides, the low-energy quasiparticle (QP) dynamics in strongly electronically correlated cuprates can be probed very efficiently via in-plane defect studies .
Today this strong suppression of T c is understood within the framework of disorder induced potential (unitary) scattering of Cooper pairs with d-wave order parameter .
The second striking effect of these non-magnetic defects is the impurity induced magnetism.

Electron paramagnetic resonance , nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) , and bulk magnetic suscept- ibility [6] experiments gave some indications that isovalent non-magnetic defects like Zn give rise to a local magnetic moment-like feature on the nearest neighbors of the sub- stituted Cu sites in the CuO 2 planes.
This apparent magnetic behavior manifests itself as a Curie-like term in the bulk temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility, χ(T) [6] at low temperatures.

Some researchers have attributed this effect to the uncompensated spins (spin vacancy) in the presence of short-range antiferromagnetic correlations, arising as a result of replacing (s=1/2) Cu 2+ with isovalent and non-magnetic Zn 2+ (s=0).

On the other hand, pioneering scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) experiments on Zn substituted hole doped cuprates by Pan et al have found intense low- energy QP scattering resonances at the Zn sites, coincident with the strong suppression of superconductivity within a length scale ∼15 Å around the defect sites.
The observed magnetic behavior of impurity substituted hole doped cuprates has been modeled mainly by using two different frameworks.
Both these frameworks describe experimental results with some degree of success but the underlying physics is markedly different.

The first scenario invokes a picture where the appearance of localized spins in the neighboring Cu sites at low temperatures enhances the uniform static magnetic susceptibility, whereas the second scenario implies that the magnetic effect is basically due to weakly localized QP spectral weight, i.e., an effect arising from the electronic energy density of states (EDOS) at low- energy .
It is fair to say that the situation remains unsettled till date .
In this work we wish to address this issue from a new angle -by looking at the Zn induced suppression of superconducting transition temperature in hole doped cuprates.
We assume that the weakly localized low-energy QPs created due to Zn sub- stitution do not take part in Cooper pairing.
We also assume that, it is these QP states which induce a low-T Curie-like contrib- ution in the bulk magnetic susceptibility.
Based on these new assumptions, we have analyzed the T c suppression data and the χ(T) data for La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 with different compositions (x and y values).

paragraphs.text: A consistent picture emerges which supports the scenario where Zn induced modifications of χ(T) originates from the underlying changes in the low-energy EDOS.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. We present the experimental data in section 2. Analysis of data is presented in section 3. Results of analysis of are discussed in section 4. Finally, section 5 consists of the concluding remarks.
Polycrystalline single-phase sintered samples of La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 were synthesized by standard solid-state reaction methods using high-purity starting materials.

paragraphs.text: The following powdered chemicals supplied by Aldrich were used (purity is given in brackets): La 2 O 3 (99.999%), SrCO 3 (99.995%), CuO (99.9999%) and ZnO (99.999%).

paragraphs.text: All these compounds were dried in clean alumina crucibles in a furnace at 500°C for 10 h so as to eliminate any water absorbed (which could lead to stoi- chiometric errors) in the chemicals.
The final sintering was done at 1010°C for 12 h under high-purity flowing air following a number of intermediate steps at lower temperatures.

The densities of the sintered pellets were high ∼6.2 g/c.c., where the ideal x-ray crystal density is ∼7.0 g/c.c. Parts of the pellets were ground for x-ray and AC magnetic susceptibility (ACS) mea- surements.
Samples were characterized by x-ray powder dif- fraction, room-temperature thermopower, ACS measurements.
Details of sample preparation and characterization can be found in .
χ(T) measurements were done using a model 1822 Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer.
Field cooled magnetization data were collected following a predefined sequence, usually in the range of 5-400 K, under an applied dc magnetic field of 5 Tesla.
The sample was mounted inside a quartz tube, held firmly between two inner tubes.
The back- ground signals from the quartz tubes were subtracted from the data to obtain the magnetic moment of the sample and to cal- culate the molar susceptibility.
The raw data is actually the convoluted signal consisting of two separate signals from the sample and the quartz tubes.
We have performed background measurements without the sample using the same sequence and scan length (6 cm).
The difference between the two gives the background corrected magnetization of the sample from which the molar bulk magnetic susceptibility was calculated.
This subtraction method holds as long as the distance between the inner quartz tubes is the same as the length of the sample.
The background magnetic moment is almost T-independent.

In this study we have used two different Sr contents-x=0.09 (underdoped) and 0.15 (close to the optimum doping), each with the following nominal Zn concentrations-y=0.0, 0.005, 0.01, 0.015, 0.02, and 0.024.

The actual level of Sr content in the synthesized samples can be checked from the room-temperature thermopower [13] and the Zn induced suppression of super- conducting T c gives a reliable estimate about the actual level of Zn in the CuO 2 plane in La214 .

paragraphs.text: The reported values of Sr content in this paper are accurate within ±0.005 and the actual Zn contents are quite close to the nominal concentrations (approximately within ±0.1%).

1. Copper K α1 radiation was used (wavelength 1.541 Å).
Within the resolution of the x-ray diffractometer, the samples were found to be almost phase pure.
In a few of the compounds impurity phases (mainly LaCuO 3 ) with an intensity less than 1% was detected.

The T c values with different hole and Zn contents are tabulated in table

1. T c was taken at the point where the line drawn on the steepest part of the diamagnetic ACS curve meets the almost T-independent base line associated with the negligibly small normal state ACS signal (an illustrative example is shown in the inset of figure 2).
T c values are accurate within ±0.5 K. The variation of T c with Zn content for different hole con- centrations is shown in figure
2. The room-temperature thermopower is sensitive to the hole content and therefore, to the Sr content in LSCO .

paragraphs.text: 3. It is worth noticing that the background moment is positive.
Pure quartz, on the other hand, is diamagnetic in nature.
The positive background moment almost certainly comes from some paramagnetic minerals as impurities present in the quartz.
The background signal corrected χ(T) data are shown in figure
4. Inspection of these data reveals that a Curie-like enhancement appears only at low-T in the uniform magnetic susceptibility and increases systematically with Zn content.
The increment is markedly stronger in the underdoped compounds.

At this point, it is worth mentioning that, unlike in the case of magnetic Ni or Co substituted high-T c compounds [18], the Curie-like increase in the magnetic susceptibility due to non-magnetic Zn appears only at relatively low-T region.
There is also a gradual suppression of high-T χ(T).
These two effects toge- ther can lead to a crossing point in χ(T) which shifts to lower T with increasing hole content (see .
It is widely believed that, in some way or other, the low-T enhancement a.s. arises due to the strong electronic correlations and the pseudogap (PG) present in the host material .
It is seen from figure 2 that irrespective of hole content, Zn suppresses T c almost linearly.

The rate of suppression dT c /dy, is significantly higher for the underdoped compound (dT c /dy=−12.1/%Zn and −16.2/%Zn for x=0.15 and x=0.09 compounds, respectively as found in previous stu- dies ).
This hole content dependent value of dT c /dy can be accounted for by considering a Zn induced pair-breaking picture in the unitary limit .
In this scenario, each non-magnetic Zn roughly breaks a d-wave Cooper pair where the pair-breaking scattering rate varies inversely with the

paragraphs.text: EDOS around the Fermi level.
The usual pair-breaking scheme can be expressed as [22]: Here, Ψ is the digamma function, T c0 =T c (y=0), and Γ is the pair-breaking scattering rate (in energy unit), for potential scattering.
This scattering rate can be expressed as Γ=y/πN(ε F ).
N(ε F ) should be taken as the thermally aver- aged (over a temperature window of width ∼± 2k B T c about the Fermi energy) EDOS around the Fermi level.
Assuming a triangular PG , one can calculate the pair- breaking scattering rate within this framework.
The pair- breaking scattering rate is found to vary as T * /T c for a fixed impurity concentration, y.
T * is the characteristic PG temp- erature, related roughly to the characteristic PG energy scale, ε g ≡k B T * .
This scheme, therefore, provides one with a nat- ural explanation for the hole content dependent values of dT c /dy in terms of the PG in the QP spectral density.

PG increases with underdoping and thereby reduces the EDOS at the Fermi level, which in turn increases the pair-breaking scattering rate and T c is reduced more rapidly with impurity content as a consequence.
For deeply overdoped compounds, where PG is absent, the scattering rate should become nearly constant and dT c /dy should become almost hole content independent, as is seen in experiments .
We have shown the hole content dependent rate of sup- pression of T c and the corresponding PG energy scales for in figure 5.
shows a clear anti- correlation between dT c (p)/dy and ε g (p).
This is a generic feature followed by all the different families of hole doped cuprates .
shows the experimental χ(T, p) data of the com- pounds under study.
In previous studies we have demonstrated that the χ(T, p) behavior of different hole doped cuprate families follows mainly from the p and T dependent Pauli spin susceptibility (χ s ) part.
The p and T dependent features of χ(T, p) primarily follow from the p dependent PG energy scale .
Strong experimental support is found from the analysis of specific heat and NMR data .
In many ways, results obtained from χ(T, p) complement those obtained from the pioneering specific heat studies by Loram et al .
One of the most unambiguous measures of QP spectral density is obtained from the electronic specific heat coefficient, γ.
The striking qualitative and quantitative resemblance between bulk magnetic susceptibility and electronic specific heat has been well documented .
χ s (T, p) and S(T, p)/T (where the electronic entropy S(T, p)=∫ γ(T, p)dT) show

completely identical T dependences.
Furthermore, the value of S/χ s T is very close to the free electron Wilson ratio p m º a k 3 .
The similar T-dependences of S/T and χ s show that the total spin and charge excitation spectrum have similar energy dependences.

The fact that S/χ s T∼a 0 , does not require that the respective QP spectra are those of free electrons, but rather that the relative number of thermally excited charge and spin excitations is that expected for con- ventional Fermions in cuprates, even in the presence of strong electronic correlations in these materials.

Based on the above experimental and theoretical indi- cations and our previous analysis of the χ(T, p) data for different families of cuprates, including , we propose a simple model to analyze the Zn induced behavior of χ(T, p) as follows.
We assume that the QPs within the resonance peak appear at the expense of the states on the flanks of the PG, thereby expanding the PG locally (see .

This takes into account the experimental observation that χ(T)T for different Zn concentration at a given hole content, are not parallel at high-T (the apparent 'melting' of Zn induced 'magnetic moment' at high-T) for underdoped compounds.
From this it can be inferred that there are no extra states inside the PG region in the EDOS, only a rearrangement of electronic states take place.
An approximated resonance bar of width 2ε can be employed to fit the uniform magnetic susceptibility of Zn- doped LSCO.

paragraphs.text: One can also approximate the QP resonance with a Lorentzian profile .
A resonance bar or a Lor- entzian yields almost identical qualitative and quantitative results.

Following our earlier analyses , we have used the following expression to model the magnetic uniform In this equation, N 0 is related to the electronic density of states of the host LSCO outside the PG region.

attributes.material0_rawTaggedValue: <name>LSCO</name>

paragraphs.text: N 1 is the amplitude of the QP resonance density of states.

The first part of the above expression on the right hand side of equation fol- lows from the successful phenomenological modeling of the PG to explain the electronic specific heat, entropy, bulk magnetic susceptibility, Knight shift and dc charge transport of different families of cuprates .
A triangular PG pinned at the Fermi level yields the first part of equation (2) when the thermal averaging of the gap function is properly done.
The most important parameter that can be reliably extracted from this model is the magnitude of the characteristic PG energy scale which agrees very well with the experimentally observed values .
The second part of equation gives the contribution to the magnetic sus- ceptibility originating from the defect (Zn) induced QP resonance .
Before proceeding any further, a few points must be clarified here.
Equation (2) models the experimental χ(T) data in terms of thermally averaged EDOS alone.
The Zn induced enhancement of χ(T) is due to the low-energy QP spectral weight in this scenario and therefore, related to the Pauli paramagnetic effect.

But the experimentally measured χ(T) generally includes several contributions to the bulk magnetic susceptibility that are not directly related to the underlying EDOS, e.g., the core (Larmor) and the Van Vleck contribu- tions.
But these contributions are believed to be temperature independent.
Landau diamagnetic term on the other hand, has the same energy dependence as the Pauli spin susceptibility.
But for hole doped cuprates, this term is only 2%-5% of the Pauli paramagnetic term in magnitude .
We therefore do not need to deal with this separately.
Thus, in equation , N 0 not only gives a measure of the flat EDOS outside the PG region, but its value also includes the T-independent

Results of representative fits to the χ s (T, p) data are shown in figure 7.
The data in the vicinity of the SC transition temperature were not used in the fits.
This is because the formalism developed does not take into account the superconducting fluctuations.
There is reason to believe that strong pairing fluctuations contributing to fluctuation diamagnetism do not exist 20-30 K above T c in La214 (∼at T>1.7 T c ) .
The simple model expressed via equation (2) fits the experimental magnetic susceptibility quite satisfactorily.
We have shown the fitting parameters in table 2.
So far, it has been established quite firmly from experimental findings, that the Zn induced magnetic effect is strongly hole content dependent.
At the same time the rate of suppression of superconducting T c is also strongly hole content dependent.
Both these observations can be linked to the evolution of the PG in the QP energy density of states with the hole content.
A depleted EDOS due to PG enhances the pair-breaking scattering rate due to impurity and T c is degraded rapidly.
Whether there was a direct link between the magnetic enhancement and T c degradation due to Zn remained as an open question.
To investigate this further, we have shown the ΔT c (p, y) and the area under the QP resonance, A(p, y), in figure 8.

reveals that when hole content is low (PG is large), T c decreases sharply with in-plane impurity content and at the same time the area under the resonance bar also increases sharply with impurity concentration.

This, we believe, is a notable evidence in favor of the scenario where the low-energy QP states are thought to form from a redis- tribution of QP states from higher energy to low-energy and these low-energy QPs are excluded from the Cooper pairing condensate.

This also supports the previous proposal that Zn induced magnetic effect in hole doped cuprates arises from the redistribution of QP spectral weight rather than appearance of localized Curie moments in the canonical sense.
At this point it should be mentioned that Kruis et al proposed a simple model where the presence of a PG ensures a low-energy resonance in the QP spectral density.
A triangular PG pinned at the Fermi level was con- sidered in , similar to what we have assumed in this study.
Another direct consequence of the proposed scenario is that it offers a natural explanation for the crossing point of the χ(T) data (figures 4
(a) and

paragraphs.text: low-energy resonance appears at the expense of the states near the edges of the PG, it leads to a decrease in the χ(T) at high temperatures (depending on the energy width of the PG) and a subsequent increase in the χ(T) in the low temperature.
These effects result quite naturally in a crossing point in the magnetic susceptibility data as impurity contents are changed.
A spin dilution effect also plays a role .
This can be traced from a gradually decreasing trend of N 0 with impurity con- centration (table 2).
The crossing temperature seems to follow the characteristic PG energy scale.
Circumstantial evidence also follows from our previous work where we have inves- tigated χ(T) of overdoped La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 .

paragraphs.text: No crossing point in χ(T) could be detected [11] in these compounds.
This, we believe, is due to the absence of PG in those com- pounds.
In this situation, as suggested by Kruis et al , the QP resonant state is formed only when the phase coherent superconducting gap is significant (i.e., below T c ).
Therefore, its effect in the normal state is absent.
exhibits the main finding of this study.
It is seen clearly that the suppression of T c (ΔT c (y)=[T c (y=0)−T c (y)]) with Zn follows closely the growth of the resonance spectral density with Zn.
In this work, we suggest that this spectral weight is removed from the superconducting con- densate and thereby reduce superfluid density.
This proposal qualitatively supports the well-known Uemura relation between superconducting transition temperature and superfluid density.
It is also consistent with the swiss cheese model on the qualitative level .
It is worth mentioning that even though A(p, y) grows linearly with Zn, the extrapolated value of A(p, y) at y=0 is non vanishing for either of the Sr contents considered in this study.
A small residual A(p, y=0) exists.

This perhaps is due to an intrinsic (related essentially to Sr substitution induced disorder) effect or an extrinsic (related to minute level of impurity phase) effect, showing that some disorder capable of generating low-energy resonant states exist in the CuO 2 plane even when Zn content is zero.
The fits to the χ(T) data give estimates of the PG energy scale.

The extracted values of ε g obtained from analysis of uniform magnetic susceptibility agree very well with those extracted from the analysis of heat capacity and charge transport data of different families of high-T c cuprates.
This gives credence to the model employed in this study.
It is important to note that even though Zn acts as an efficient suppressor of T c , it has no effect on ε g for a given hole content, within the experimental uncertainty.
This contrasting effects of Zn on T c and ε g indicate that Cooper pairing correlations and PG correlations are perhaps not directly linked to each other.
A number of previous experimental studies support this proposition .
It is also worth noting that, for a fixed value of p, the values of ε g are almost independent of the Zn content.
For example, the values of ε g are 530 ± 20 K and 245 ± 30 K for La 1.91 Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 and La 1.85 Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 , respectively.

paragraphs.text: The small and non- systematic variation in the values of ε g with Zn for each Sr concentration can be accounted for by an uncertainty in the Sr content at the level of Δx=±0.005.
In the proposed scenario, the impurity induced resonant QP spectral weight, which is excluded from pairing condensate, contributes to the low-T χ(T) of La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 .

paragraphs.text: This is consistent with the STM results pre- sented in [7].
The effect of Zn on the SC transition temperature and the bulk magnetic susceptibility has been investigated in this paper.

An attempt has been made to explain and relate the strong hole content dependences of dT c /dy and enhanced χ(T) of La 2−x Sr x Cu 1−y Zn y O 4 in terms of a model EDOS whose fea- tures are dominated by the hole content dependent PG and an impurity induced low-energy QP resonant spectral density for the first time.

paragraphs.text: This model yields values of ε g in excellent agreement with those found in earlier studies .
The model also offers a natural explanation of the crossing of χ(T, y) data for underdoped cuprates in terms of spin dilution and redistribution of QP spectral weight.
The extracted values of ε g at a given hole content are Zn independent as found in previous studies .
We have found strong indications that a common mechanism works behind suppression of T c and enhancement of χ(T) with Zn.
, a central result of this

paragraphs.text: This provides with strong evidence in favor of the scenario where Zn induced low-energy resonant states are precluded from SC pairing but contributes to the low-T enhancement of the χ(T).
Both dT c /dy and enhance- ment of χ(T) increase in magnitude with increasing under- doping.
This, we believe, is due to the doping dependent behavior of the PG.
Theoretical work by Kruis et al supports this assumption.
At both a qualitative and quantita- tive level the analyses presented in this study are strongly supported by the electronic heat capacity studies by Loram et al .

Since the coefficient of electronic specific heat, γ, and NMR Knight shifts directly probe the underlying EDOS, an analysis of these parameters for Zn substituted hole doped cuprates is expected to yield results similar to this study.
The Zn induced low-T enhancement of γ or the Knight shift should give a direct measure of the unpaired QP resonant spectral weight.
